title: 107_s2458
content: Establishment of initiatives for predominantly Muslim countries. The Congress finds that negative opinions of the United States in predominantly Muslim countries are distorted by misinformation and propaganda, which is detrimental to US interests. To improve this image, programs promoting American society and values should be established. To enhance the positive image of the United States in predominantly Muslim countries, programs promoting American society and values should be established as part of educational and cultural exchange initiatives. This includes a journalism program for foreign journalists and postsecondary students in cooperation with private sector sponsors like universities. The Department of State will establish programs with predominantly Muslim countries for educational and cultural exchange, including a journalism program for foreign journalists and postsecondary students, and a demonstration program to assist in developing public library systems. The Secretary of State will develop a program to assist foreign governments in improving public library systems to enhance literacy and education. Additionally, a program will be established to provide grants for U.S. citizens to work as English language teaching assistants in schools abroad. The Secretary will establish a program for U.S. citizens to work as English language teaching assistants in middle and secondary schools abroad. Sister city partnerships will be expanded to promote global cooperation at the community level, focusing on economic development, health care, education, and humanitarian assistance. The Secretary will establish a program for youth ambassadors from middle and secondary schools to visit the United States for cultural and educational activities during school holidays. The program aims to promote global cooperation at the community level through economic development, municipal cooperation, health care initiatives, youth and educational programs, disability advocacy, emergency preparedness, and humanitarian assistance. The Secretary will establish a program for youth ambassadors from middle and secondary schools to visit the United States for cultural and educational activities. The program aims to familiarize students with American society and values, coordinate visits with schools for interactions, and encourage school-to-school linkages. Additionally, the Secretary will seek to increase awards under the Fulbright exchange program for individuals from the United States to study, teach, or conduct research in predominantly Muslim countries. The William Fulbright Educational Exchange Program aims to increase awards for scholars and teachers from the United States to study, teach, or conduct research in predominantly Muslim countries. The program also seeks to increase the number of Hubert H. Humphrey Fellowships awarded to candidates from these countries. Programs will be carried out under specific acts governing educational and cultural exchanges. The Secretary will establish a database of American and foreign alumni from international exchange programs to promote networking and communication. Additionally, a report will be made on the inclusion of freedom and democracy advocates in educational and cultural exchange programs. The Secretary of State must submit a report to Congress within 90 days regarding the implementation of a specific section of the Human Rights, Refugee, and Other Foreign Relations Provisions Act of 1996. The report will detail the number of grants for exchange programs, measures taken to include supporters of freedom and democracy in program selection, and evaluate the openness of US exchange programs to these supporters in certain countries. The Act does not authorize visas or admission to the US for inadmissible aliens. $35,000,000 is authorized for the Department of State for fiscal years 2003 and 2004. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of State.
